destinations.name: Koraput
destinations.description: Koraput — tribal heartland known for Kotpad weave, Duduma falls, rich tribal festivals like Parab and scenic highlands.
destinations.fun_fact: Kotpad handloom and tribal weaving traditions are a unique Koraput specialty.

festivals.name: Parab
festivals.description: A major tribal festival featuring dances, music, and traditional rituals celebrated by various tribes of Koraput.

tribes.name: Paraja
tribes.description: One of the major tribal groups with rich cultural traditions.

tribes.name: Bonda
tribes.description: A distinct tribe known for traditional attire and crafts.

crafts.name: Kotpad Weaving
crafts.description: Handloom weaving with natural dyes and distinctive geometric designs.

hidden_jewels.name: Duduma Falls
hidden_jewels.description: A spectacular waterfall set in lush hills — great for trekking.

destinations.name: Kandhamal
destinations.description: Kandhamal district — a hilly, tribal-rich region of Odisha known for its unique tribal cultures (Kandha, Kutia Kondh, Dongria/Rongria Kondh), pine forests, scenic hill station Daringbadi, and famous Kandhamal Haldi (turmeric, GI-tagged).
destinations.fun_fact: Kandhamal is world-famous for Kandhamal Haldi (turmeric, GI-tagged).

festivals.name: Meriah festival
festivals.description:
It was a ritual festival of the Kondhs, dedicated to their Earth Goddess (Tari Penu / Dharni Penu) for ensuring fertility, good harvests, and community well-being.

The central feature was the human sacrifice (Meriah sacrifice) in ancient times. The victim (often called Meriah) was offered to the goddess.

festivals.name: Maranga Laka
festivals.description: Maranga Laka is a seasonal ritual offering where the Kondh people prepare cakes made from mohula flowers (from the mahula tree, also known as mahua) and present them to the village deity. This occurs during April to May, aligning with the collection of forest produce and marking the renewal of natural abundance.

festivals.name: Kedu Laka
festivals.description:
Dedicated to Dharni Penu (the Earth Goddess).

The Kondhs believe that Mother Earth must be fed with blood so that she remains fertile, ensuring good crops, prosperity, and protection of the community.

Earlier, human sacrifice (Meriah) was part of it, but now it has been replaced by the sacrifice of buffaloes, goats, fowls, and pigs.

festivals.name: Bagha Nacha
festivals.description:
Performed in the form of a tiger (Bagha) to represent strength, protection, and the forest spirit. Symbolizes the tribal belief that the tiger is both a protector and a fearsome power.

Performers paint their bodies with yellow and black stripes, resembling a tiger’s skin. They wear masks or painted faces, sometimes with tails made of cloth or rope. The entire look is so realistic that from a distance, they resemble actual tigers. Performed to the beats of tribal drums (dhol, nagara, and mahuri) and in groups with synchronized, rhythmic steps.

festivals.name: Kedu Dance
festivals.description: In earlier times, the Meriah sacrifice (human sacrifice) was a part of the ritual, later replaced by buffalo sacrifice. It is performed in honor of Dharani Penu (Mother Earth Goddess). It is done as a thanksgiving to Mother Earth for fertility and good harvest.

tribes.name: Pano
tribes.description: Pano Tribe often live alongside Kandha (Kondh) tribes and share cultural elements with them. Traditionally, they have served as artisans, weavers, drummers, and laborers in tribal societies.

tribes.name: Kandha (Kondh)
tribes.description: The major tribal group of Kandhamal, central to the district's cultural and ritual life. Many of the district's festivals and rituals (including Meriah, Kedu Laka, Maranga Laka) are rooted in Kandha traditions.

tribes.name: Kutia Kondh
tribes.description: The Kutia Kondh are a Particularly Vulnerable Tribal Group (PVTG) of Odisha. They are a subgroup of the larger Kondh (Kandha) tribe. They mainly live in the Tumudibandha, Belghar, and Lanjigarh areas of Kandhamal and Kalahandi districts. They practice shifting cultivation (podu chasa) — growing millets, maize, pulses, turmeric — and depend on forests for food (tubers, fruits, honey), fuelwood, and medicinal plants. Rituals often include animal sacrifice (buffalo, goats, fowls) to appease deities.

tribes.name: Rongria / Dongria Kondh
tribes.description: The Dongria (Rongria) Kondh are one of the most well-known Particularly Vulnerable Tribal Groups (PVTGs) of Odisha. They mainly inhabit the Niyamgiri Hills. Their supreme deity is Niyam Raja (Niyamraja), the protector god of Niyamgiri Hills.

crafts.name: Dokra & Bamboo Crafts
crafts.description: Local tribal handicrafts such as dokra metalwork (lost-wax technique), bamboo weaving and tribal jewelry are significant in Kandhamal's cultural economy.

hidden_jewels.name: Putundi Waterfall
hidden_jewels.description: The waterfall is formed by the Bada Saluki River, which plunges down nearly 60 ft (18 meters) amidst dense forests. It’s a popular picnic spot, especially during winter and post-monsoon when the water flow is strong. Local people consider the area around the waterfall sacred and often visit for small rituals or festivals.

hidden_jewels.name: Ludu Waterfall
hidden_jewels.description: It lies deep inside the forest, surrounded by hills and tribal villages, making it a relatively less explored destination. Water falls from a rocky hill into a natural pool, creating a refreshing picnic spot. Dense forests and chirping birds add to the charm of the place. Still less commercialized, so it retains its raw natural beauty.

hidden_jewels.name: Mandasaru
hidden_jewels.description: Mandasaru is one of the hidden natural treasures of Kandhamal district, often called the "Silent Valley of Odisha" for its untouched wilderness and breathtaking views. It is home to rare medicinal plants, orchids, and wildlife and is a hotspot for eco-tourism.

hidden_jewels.name: Daringbadi
hidden_jewels.description: Around 915 meters (3,000 ft) above sea level. The only hill station of Odisha, famous for its pine forests, coffee plantations, and occasional snowfall in peak winter. Inhabited mainly by the Kandha and Kutia Kondh tribes. Visitors can experience their traditional lifestyle, crafts, and festivals.

hidden_jewels.name: Baraladevi Temple
hidden_jewels.description: The temple is dedicated to Goddess Baraladevi, considered a powerful form of Shakti (Mother Goddess). She is worshipped as the protector of the region and holds deep reverence among the tribal and local communities. The temple is an important Shakti Peetha in Kandhamal.

hidden_jewels.name: Belghar
hidden_jewels.description: Surrounded by forests and hills. Famous for Kutia Kondh tribes and wildlife (elephants, bison). Belghar Nature Camp is an eco-tourism hub. Tribal villages here allow visitors to experience Kondh and Pano traditions, music, dance, and festivals. The area is also known for dokra art, bamboo crafts, and tribal jewelry.

hidden_jewels.name: Tribal Villages & Eco Camps
hidden_jewels.description: Small tribal villages across Kandhamal offer authentic cultural experiences — traditional music, dance, dokra art, bamboo crafts, and tribal jewelry. Eco-camps and nature walks provide opportunities to observe wildlife and learn about forest-dependent livelihoods.

destinations.name: Ganjam
destinations.description: Ganjam district — known for rich textile traditions, Danda Nacha, Kandhei Jatra, Bharata Lila, coastal ecotourism and vibrant crafts.
destinations.fun_fact: Famous for silk Patto sarees, Bomkai weaving, and brass 'pitala macha' (fish crafts).

festivals.name: Danda Nacha / Danda Nata
festivals.description: A ritual dance drama dedicated to Goddess Kali and Lord Shiva, performed annually in Chaitra (March-April). Dancers, called 'danduas', undergo self-imposed austerities and perform barefoot on streets, enact hard rituals like Dhuli Danda (mud rituals), Pani Danda (water rituals), and Agni Danda (fire rituals). This intense festival has origins dating back to the 8th and 9th centuries.

festivals.name: Kandhei Jatra
festivals.description: An age-old festival featuring traditional wooden dolls (Kandhei), mainly celebrated in select parts of Ganjam. In this festival dolls are offered to budhi thakurani (an age old temple in Berhampur).

festivals.name: Bharata Lila (Duari Nata)
festivals.description: It is a performing theater form of Ganjam district of Odisha. The plot is based on characters of the Mahabharata, thus the name of the form. Because of the importance of a central character Duari, Arjuna's sentry, it is also called Duari Nata or Duari Lila. The focal point of the plot is the story of Arjuna & Subhadra's romance, which is why it is also known as Subhadra Harana.

tribes.name: Saora (Sabar)
tribes.description: The Saora tribe is a prominent group in the undivided Ganjam district and remains a subject of research and interest in the region.

tribes.name: Kandha Gauda
tribes.description: A specific group within the Kandha community found in the district.

tribes.name: Dal
tribes.description: This tribe is also listed as being present in the Ganjam region.

crafts.name: Silk Saree Weaving
crafts.description: While Ganjam is known as the 'Silk City,' its unique weaving patterns and traditional Odia designs, especially the Patto sarees, are deeply tied to ceremonial events and represent living heritage.

crafts.name: Ganjam Fish (Pitala Macha)
crafts.description: Traditional, flexible brass fish toys crafted by the Kansari brass-worker community, considered auspicious and often found in bridal trousseaus; each piece involves intricate handwork and reflects ancient metalwork skills.

crafts.name: Bomkai Silk Sarees
crafts.description: While not strictly tribal, the weaving of Bomkai sarees by artisans in Ganjam reflects a blend of tribal motifs and local weaving traditions, highly valued in Odisha.

crafts.name: Stone Carving
crafts.description: Hereditary artisans (Sttapatis and Silpis) continue to create intricate temple sculptures and decorative items, maintaining centuries-old techniques.

crafts.name: Palm Leaf Paintings
crafts.description: Decorative arts that are integral to Ganjam’s identity, yet remain less publicized compared to Odisha’s mainstream crafts.

hidden_jewels.name: Blackbuck Conservation Villages
hidden_jewels.description: About 70 villages in the northern Eastern Ghats of Ganjam (particularly in the Bhetnoi village) have conserved shy blackbucks for over a century. Tourists can enjoy wildlife spotting and guided nature walks to see these near-threatened antelopes in open grasslands surrounded by hills.

hidden_jewels.name: Taptapani Hot Sulfur Springs
hidden_jewels.description: Known for its medicinal properties, Taptapani is a hot spring spot where visitors can experience natural warm waters and scenic surroundings, offering a tranquil escape.

hidden_jewels.name: Tampara Lake
hidden_jewels.description: A sweet water lake near National Highway No.5 that offers serene boat rides and gentle water sport activities in a natural setting, away from busy tourist crowds.

hidden_jewels.name: Adventure Sports near Berhampur
hidden_jewels.description: In and around Berhampur in Ganjam, adventure seekers can find opportunities for skydiving, paragliding, bungee jumping, white-water rafting, scuba diving, and jet skiing. These thrilling sports are available but not heavily advertised, making them hidden gems for adrenaline lovers.

hidden_jewels.name: Sonapur (Sonpur) Beach
hidden_jewels.description: Situated around 30 km from Berhampur, Sonapur Sea Beach is a pristine and quiet destination with clean sands and scenic views. Even locals acknowledge its untouched, peaceful vibe and infrequent visitors.

hidden_jewels.name: Jaugada Fort
hidden_jewels.description: An ancient fort site dating back to the Mauryan era, associated with Emperor Ashoka. Archaeological remains here signify its importance as a historical military and administrative site.

hidden_jewels.name: Chilika Lake (Rambha)
hidden_jewels.description: Rambha area of Chilika Lake has historical significance due to British-era establishments and as part of the ancient trade route.

hidden_jewels.name: Kalijai Temple
hidden_jewels.description: It is a famous and revered temple located on an island in Chilika Lake, Odisha. It is dedicated to Goddess Kalijai, regarded as an incarnation of Goddess Kali and the first Mahavidya of the Dasmahavidyas. According to local legend, the temple’s origin traces back to a tragic story of a newlywed girl named Jaai, who, along with her father, was crossing Chilika Lake by boat to reach her husband's village on an island. A severe cyclone caused the boat to capsize, and while the boatman and her father survived, Jaai drowned. The local people began worshipping her as the goddess Kalijai, symbolizing protection for those traveling on the lake.

hidden_jewels.name: Balakumari Temple
hidden_jewels.description: It is a renowned Hindu temple situated atop the scenic Kerandimala mountain in Ganjam district, Odisha. The temple is dedicated to Maa Balakumari, a form of Goddess Durga, who is believed to fulfill the wishes of devotees. The temple was built around the 8th century CE during the Bhaumakara dynasty and features intricate Odishan architecture with carvings of divine beings.

hidden_jewels.name: Panchama Temple (Sidha Vinayaka)
hidden_jewels.description: Also known as Sidha Vinayaka Temple Panchama, a sacred Hindu shrine located about 16 km from Berhampur in the village of Panchama. Dedicated to Lord Ganesha worshipped as Siddha Vinayaka, the idol is housed in the hollow trunk of a large Peepal tree which adds to the temple’s unique spiritual aura. The temple's origins date back to the 8th century AD.

hidden_jewels.name: Bariapathara / Bariapathar Waterfall
hidden_jewels.description: Located at the border of Ganjam and formed by the Mahendra Tanaya river, Bariapathar is a scenic and secluded waterfall surrounded by hills. It’s considered one of the most beautiful and largest hidden waterfalls in Ganjam, ideal for nature lovers and picnics.

hidden_jewels.name: Budhakhol Waterfall
hidden_jewels.description: Nestled amidst the picturesque landscapes of Ganjam near Buguda, Budhakhol Waterfall and its surrounding cave temples offer serene beauty and a touch of mystery. The area around the waterfall is dotted with ancient Buddhist caves, making it an interesting offbeat destination.

hidden_jewels.name: Bagha Chanchada (Pather Chanchada) Waterfall
hidden_jewels.description: A tourist spot in the Chikitipentho region of Ganjam, also called Pather Chanchada. Scenic and quieter compared to other falls.

hidden_jewels.name: Siddha Bhairabi Temple
hidden_jewels.description: A renowned Shakti shrine located in Mantridi village, about 18 kilometers from Berhampur. Dedicated to Goddess Bhairavi (Eka Pada Bhairavi). The temple complex houses 108 subsidiary shrines dedicated to various Hindu deities.
